Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Ecological and evolutionary dynamics in temporally autocorrelated landscapes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Uncertainty about how species respond to changing environmental conditions is exacerbated by human growth and development, which is increasing the fragmentation of natural landscapes all over the world. This project combines a new theoretical approach to environmental variation in space and time with experimental manipulation of habitat fragmentation to examine extinction risk at large spatial scales. It challenges current understanding of the relationship between environmental variation and extinction risk by providing a more realistic spatio-temporal context for ecological processes. When environmental change is similar, or correlated, among discrete populations that are separated spatially, this change can synchronize population fluctuations, enhancing the risk of extinction. The investigators have recently demonstrated that differences among populations in the degree of environmental correlations reduce population synchrony. This project will test these novel findings using laboratory experiments that vary dispersal rates and environmental dynamics in discrete populations of protists and bacteria.

This project will enhance the training of a promising doctoral student. The research also provides unique opportunities for young scientists for cross-disciplinary training in mathematics and experimental ecology through an ongoing after-school program run by the Yale University Peabody Museum. Simultaneously, the doctoral student will gain experience mentoring these younger, incipient researchers. The investigators will also develop an on-line demonstration that uses results from this research to explain the relationships between environmental change and population responses to this change. The demonstration will allow general users to manipulate factors such as growth rate, dispersal rate, and environmental change to understand the effects they have on population dynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main purpose of this project is to better understand how fluctuating environmental conditions can affect species extinction risk. Environmental fluctuations can synchronize different populations of the same species across space, which increases regional extinction risk by increasing the likelihood that multiple local populations go extinct simultaneously. Here we focus specifically on how spatial population synchrony is affected by the temporal structure of the environment, which is known to vary among environmental variables (for example, temperature and precipitation) and across space.  We conducted experiments in the laboratory in which microbial communities (ciliates) were subjected to fluctuating temperatures and found that, when environmental fluctuations have different temporal autocorrelation structures across space, populations can exhibit higher levels of synchrony than expected based on the amount of synchrony between their environments alone, contrary to the conventional understanding about environmentally induced population synchrony set up by P. A. P. Moran in the 1950’s. We formally explained this phenomenon using mathematical models, showing that population synchrony depends not only on the temporal structure of the environment, but also on the way that populations filter environmental information, which in turn depends upon population growth rate. We also developed a series of mathematical models to understand evolutionary responses to fluctuating environmental conditions, finding that the temporal structure of the environment can determine whether populations are able to evolve traits to tolerate environmental stress due to potential tradeoffs between stress tolerance and other traits that affect fitness. Taken together, these results suggest that species extinction risk may be underestimated without taking into account the temporal structure of the environment, which has important implications for species conservation and management, especially in patchy/developed landscapes. The results of these experiments and theory have now been presented to the broader scientific community at national conferences and multiple manuscripts have been drafted, which are intended for publication in top scientific journals in the fields of ecology and evolutionary biology. Furthermore, this research supported the professional development of students at multiple levels, including undergraduate, masters, and doctoral students.
